item.title: Applying the Unix Philosophy
item.description:
I program a game in my free time. One of my first problems is asset management. A game has to load various different sounds, images, models, animations, etc.

In the case of images, we will need to possibly handle.

  • BMP
  • JPG
  • PNG
  • PSD
  • TIFF

Each format requires a method for parsing the contents of these files, retrieving information and extracting a bitmap. At maximum, this brings 5 dependencies into my project. Each dependency will require me to implement three functions at minimum. That’s 15 functions now. In the future, it can be 30.

item.title: When picking up a new programming language
item.description:
Are you a different animal, but the same beast? BRYANT, KOBE

A programming language is a means for instructing a computer to perform operations. To distinguish itself from the others, each programming language decides on the fundamentals it will provide to facilitate describing and organizing these operations. There is no objective reason behind what will or will not be provided. Hypothetically, a language could be made that provides all of the methods created to describe operations. In practice though, it never happens. It begs the question. Why is that?
